review_title: Sad to have seen LLS change so drastically since starting with the org.
pros: LLS does amazing work in advocacy, research, education, patient resources, and community fundraising events. It has been inspiring to see that the work we do and its direct impact towards fighting blood cancers. The volunteers are inspiring and wonderful to work with. We receive a fair amount of time off and a flexible work from home schedule is appreciated. I truly appreciate the focus on diversity, equity and inclusion.
cons: The organization is incredibly short staffed and field staff I know in several regions are burnt out and looking outside of the organization for other opportunities. Many of us do not feel supported in our overwhelming workloads - WE NEED MORE STAFF. There is a definite disconnect between leadership and local field staff. We have lost several employees due to so many restructures, crazy workloads during campaign season, low pay, and low morale. After several years with the organization, I am also resigning because I am burnt out and do not foresee anything changing anytime soon. I am very sad to leave, and I hope LLS can make some major changes to their org structure, pay scale, and number of people they employ.

pros: The mission, the volunteers, and your coworkers will make your position at LLS so rewarding. The heart that goes into the work on the ground is motivating and inspiring. It is a professional fundraising organization where field staff will receive training unlike any I have ever received in a nonprofit position before - it has given me the tools and training that truly turned me into a fundraising professional - you don't have to figure it out on your own.
cons:
LLS was of course impacted by the pandemic, and it required a reorganization in the summer of 2020. Our new Chief Operating Officer, Troy Dunmire, and the rest of our leadership was very transparent that there would be layoffs, and generally staff understood why that was necessary. The remaining staff worked harder than we ever have before, and it led the organization to fundraising highs, with some signature campaigns raising more than they ever did pre-pandemic. 

We worked hard believing that there was an end in sight- that leadership was indeed aware of the fact that we were running extraordinarily lean and that we would receive the resources and staff we needed once we came out the other side. Well, we are out the other side, and leadership sees nothing but dollar signs in their eyes. I believe that this is because Troy brought over many of the people he used to work with at GAP, and they approach our organization like the retail establishment they came from.

They won't address our headcount, even when faced with severe employee burnout and a mass exodus of field staff. We're not asking for them to hire back every position that existed before the reorganization, but there are clear instances where one additional headcount would make all the difference.

It feels like a hard line to take - the less the organization spends on staff the more money goes to the mission, more money to the mission is a good thing. But this is short term thinking. When you lose field staff, you lose important relationships with community members who drive the revenue of the organization. When you place this much pressure on field staff, they leave faster. It all leads to a circular effect where in 5 to 10 years revenue has begun ticking in the wrong direction. We are not GAP store workers who are easily replaceable - we are more akin to professional sales staff with specialized knowledge. We deserve to be treated as such.

It is one thing to use the pandemic to realign focus, to shift resources to campaigns that are working and cut losses on campaigns that aren't. With one exception, we were not in that position. Pre-pandemic, LLS was a rocket ship to the moon - our campaigns were growing, volunteers had an excellent experience when they worked with us and wanted to continue engaging, and we were able to put more dollars than ever towards our important mission. I sincerely hope I am wrong, but with valuable staff members leaving in droves and the lack of caring that it seems Troy has for his remaining staff, it feels like we're about to take a slow but inevitable nosedive.

They say they do, but they continue to let people go under the "restructure" title. They are operating with the retail mentality about people in that everyone is replaceable. There is no value in developing or retaining great employees. It is very sad because this is the opposite of the culture that LLS used to have.

review_title: An update to a prior review...
pros: Honestly, the only pro at this point is the warm fuzzy feeling you get from feeling like you're making a difference within the NFP space. Coworkers are great, outside of the c-suite team.
cons:
Went through a massive reorg in the middle of COVID, and laid off 10% of the staff. Would've been fine if they pulled back on the reach of the organization to accommodate and rebuild, but instead, the remaining employees were told to pick up the slack with no salary restructure or raise. Hard to stay motivated when we're expected to do 3x the work, all while we're fundraising record-breaking amounts of money, despite the pandemic. Wouldn't it make sense to pay the people we have, versus spending endless amounts of time and money on onboarding and new hire training?

The org is hemorrhaging staff, and c-suite acts as if they don't understand why. New COO has never worked in nonprofit, and is driving the org into the ground. I found out he also has been bringing a ton of former GAP higher ups on board for his team, and they are all treating this organization as a retail company. We're in the people industry, and hosting enjoyable fundraising events and cultivating relationships with our donors is the most important job we have. Taking away an elevated experience has led to longtime donors and volunteers walking away.

I'm burnt out. I'm mentally checked out. I told my boss if I didn't get a meaningful raise due to the amount of work I've taken on and the crazy amount of money we raised last year, that I would be out the door. I can't wait to leave.

review_title: Excellent Mission, Impactful Work, Fantastic Co-Workers
pros:
Mission- The impact LLS has on cancer research and support to patients is best in the world. I am honored to be part of the team helping fund these programs- especially Beat AML and the Children's Initiative. 

Impactful Work- Working alongside volunteers and dedicated staff to bring funds and awareness to the LLS mission has been the highlight of my career. 

Fantastic Co-Workers- From top leadership to fundraising campaign specialists and managers, LLS staff are amazing to work with. Even though sometimes there is disagreement on how to accomplish some things, it is evident that everyone has the mission and our patients as a priority for every decision. 

Financially stable- We had a staff reduction this year due to the pandemic's impact on funds raised, but we made a pivot, adjusted targets and remain financially stable with our new targets. Not too many non-profits can say that right now.
cons:
Communication and implementation of the new operating model was accelerated due to COVID, which did cause some confusion and lack of trust with the change. There is also less traditional career growth opportunities throughout the organization due to role eliminations at leadership levels - which is not a surprise given the staff reductions that were needed to keep the organization viable this year. I do believe the change will in time make LLS stronger in supporting our patients, but it will take a little time to get through the change. 

Diversity, equality and inclusion is finally a priority, but additional work needs to continue in order to make LLS more diverse especially at the senior leadership level.

review_title: A Great Mission Weighed Down By Metrics and Management
pros: Working my way up through a Light the Night internship, I found myself in a fulltime role as a Campaign Specialist for Student Series following my undergraduate studies. I learned very quickly that LLS is an organization that works very hard to provide part-time, full-time and intern team members with unique experiences that help those individuals grow in their fields of interest. The best aspects of LLS were the people the mission brought together; through survivor stories and connections to staff who wanted more than a typical 9-5, I knew that when I was at the office I was surrounded by people who had their heart in the fight. I was promoted very quickly to lead my own campaign and found that while it was extremely difficult, the organization saw potential in me. This is a great stepping stone for those interested in working full-time in the nonprofit sector.
cons: The numbers, the numbers, the numbers. I got so tired of hearing "do what drives revenue first," as it started to become this age-old saying that kept staff at the office until late hours, and Student Series staff driving on the roads for ridiculous KPI/quota achievements. It felt like leadership - locally - was not always willing to put up a fight against "national standards" that just didn't work in our region. It was as if when we formulated a recruitment plan/cultivation/stewardship strategy, we'd get a brief moment to entertain the thought until it was shut down completely by conflicting national priorities. Living through the recruitment cycle for schools was daunting enough, but the organization didn't do much in my view to support local chapters that had gone through natural disasters by adjusting KPIS or performance indicators. In some ways, this is good externally because I can say no nonprofit has ever pushed me this hard - which means staff members truly were being burnt out to the brink of leaving, and in essence this translated to getting as much value out of employees possible (positive use of donor dollars). But sometimes this was just overboard. When the organization decided that company-wide layoffs were on the horizon, the CEO's transparency was a nice respite from what had otherwise felt like large gaps in effective/genuine communication between lower level staff and national staff prior to COVID. DCEs (our regional oversight, working for national) were supportive to a degree, but also had their own priorities which made conversations about "how is life" feel largely artificial, and more like a report card check-in. To the point, why check in on your local staff and ask how they are doing when largely it's just a touchpoint for those individuals? I can say honestly I would not want to work in the Student Series department again having seen how heavy handed the numbers are, and with the rise of COVID-19, I worry that recruitment is a near impossibility. Meaning, if you apply for an LLS role related to school and youth initiatives, be extremely concerned for your job security. I was let go with nothing more to really do, as you can't raise money from schools with those schools closed. LLS is connected to its mission and uses the donor dollars well, but has a long way to go before earning 4 or 5 stars; middle management - even executive directors - need to prioritize the health of their local chapter staff before badgering them for monthly quota updates. I was extremely disappointed when I tried to have a heart to heart about career options and departure options with my manager, who shut me down very quickly and essentially asked "why would we invest more time in you if you're just going to leave?" That's no way to incentivize your staff to stay. All in all, if you're considering LLS, be cautious. You'll hear that the "cure to cancer is in our blood" as the mantra, but should consider that the blood, sweat and tears you put in may not (and likely won't) match up to the compensation and work/life balance you're working towards.

job_title: Senior Campaign Manager in Harrisburg, PA
pros:
LLS is drastically different depending on the chapter and the campaign in which you work on. National office is trying to implement campaign standards to make a more cohesive experience.

I have been at LLS for over 3 years in Man & Woman of the Year and I love my job. I have the freedom to make my campaign my own, I have the trust of my manager and the regional and national staff. I have learned SO MUCH about science and cancer research and about compassionate leadership. Fundraising is essentially a sales position though, no question. If you do well you get a lot of recognition and incentives. If not, it can be tough. Time off and benefits are great, but is really hard to feel good about using them until you start to feel comfortable in the job.

Networking is a HUGE part of the job. Great for moving to a new city because your whole job is to get to know the players in the city!
cons:
The first 1.5 years. Generally speaking most campaigns are on yearly cycles, so it takes a whole year to see all aspects of a campaign. It isn't until the 2nd and 3rd year that you start to feel confident in making your job your own.

There is little to know training- it is sink or swim in the first year, which really isn't fair and definitely leads to turn over. Staff is scarce and everyone has full plates, which means when you are first hired you are held to your quotas and revenue goals right away.

review_title: Inspiring organization.  Very poor management and communication.  Staff and volunteers are beyond stressed.
pros: High level vision and inspiring mission (when it's visible), most salaries, and the direct service to many patients are very positive.  Working with volunteers makes a lot of other challenges bearable.
cons: Still in indescribable transition (it's been three+ years), the effects are a terrible and continuing lack of communication, no training, dotted lines that are really just fog, and no consistent leadership plan. With another RIF in July.  How do you hire 50 new positions and staff in one year, and have to lay off another 50 12 months later?  The organization is in turmoil, some individual little parts working OK, but none of them to reasonable expectation due to near total lack of coordination between programs, fundraising, marketing, training, information.  HR is nearly useless, responses taking ages.  But that's not actually unique to HR either.  The status quo now is inaction, lack of accountability, and lack of just simple understanding. Everybody holding on to what they think they can do but, out in the fields anyway, the feeling is bad.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in White Plains, NY
pros: Excellent benefits, great mission, potentially interesting work
cons:
Management and HR do not know what they are doing.  I never got a job description.  I never got annual goals.  Rarely spoke to my direct manager and when I did the answer was "ask your peers"   There was an environment of secrecy.  Any suggestions were taken as over-stepping.  Management was through intimidation and threat.  

My department was predominantly Subcontinental Indian male.  If you are not an Asian or a male you really do not belong there.  The work could be creative and interesting.  Senior management has their own view of what needs to be done and a different way is not acceptable or even welcomed.  Short term cost over-rides long term benefits.   A constant theme was that once you stopped caring about doing quality work, you get along better and are happier.   If you wanted to do a good job, there was no support to do so.  There was plenty of support for mediocrity.   

HR did not properly onboard.  Forms were not properly filed.  Took forever to get a key to the door.  Did not intercede when there was no job description/annual goals.  

I quit because I could not longer stand the pressure of never knowing what I supposed to be doing and then being literally yelled at when I asked for an answer.

review_title: Great Company Mission, Poor cultural environment

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Incredible research resulting from the fundraising.  The people not at the executive level in the national office are mostly incredible to work with.  Most chapters have amazing staff. 

The years the org as a whole surpassed budget, the benefits package was great for me (under 40, single, no kids, general good health).
cons:
The salary increases that came out of left field (though much appreciated!) did not apply fairly - they were applied to only campaign staff and not to administrative staff in the Chapter level.  I advocated successfully for my direct report to be part of that pay bump, which I am proud of and she certainly deserved.  My managers failed me though and despite having 10 years of professional experience, I was making the same as my direct report who had 2 years experience.  

After a much needed org-wide technology upgrade & initiative - several hundred thousand dollars at my chapter alone, and the pay increased mentioned above, we had major layoffs last than four months later. 

For campaign staff in the major metropolitan areas, when there isn't an actual event occuring: unrealistic expectation be available via email or phone to volunteers off-hours.  Many volunteers are high level corporate types used to being on call and expect their campaign contacts to be on call 24/7.

pros: One of the best things about LLS is that I always feel welcome and like my work is appreciated. The second part of that is so important. Many places I have worked where I am not a paid employee (either intern or volunteer) use your services or help, but often make you feel as if you are expendable. I understand that mentality, but it does make an intern or volunteer feel very invigorated to continue to help out. LLS has always made me feel like whatever task I am doing is important and helpful, and is contributing to the difference that LLS is trying to make in the world.
cons: All of that being said, I think that if you were a patient, sometimes LLS can be a little difficult to get in contact with. Because they reduced the number of patient access managers, those who are left are stretched so thin that I think it is very easy for people to fall through the cracks. This is not a criticism of the patient access managers themselves, but rather the reduction of their numbers.

review_title: Good organization with unfortunate cultural problems
job_title: Campaign Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: LLS has a great mission to, unlike many cancer organizations which focus on awareness, prevention, etc, focuses on funding research and clinical trials to find cures for blood cancers. The national organization's unrelenting focus and achievements are admirable and due to the work of many passionate employees. I encountered many kind and super motivated people in my time with LLS.
cons: The company culture was toxic, cliquey, gossipy, and snide. Senior staff would cut staff members short, visibly roll their eyes and shut down clarifying questions or comments in meetings. Employees favored by senior management were united in trying to isolate some managers, laughing openly that they would be fired in short time. Often new employees would find that they were either "in the club" or not quickly. Those who weren't would have their performance picked apart, each apparent flaw used to justify their bad fit with the organization. It was a sad, alienating place for some and a cool, hard-nosed New York City power position for others.

pros:
Organization mission - always felt they were doing right by the donations received and it was great working for something bigger than yourself
Meeting patients/volunteers
Decent salary for non-profits in the area
Excellent benefits and PTO - quickly accumulated additional vacation time
Position allowed for a flexible schedule and the opportunity to meet tons of new people
Some ability for promotion, depending on chapter situation
Great opportunity for younger employees to learn/improve upon a wide variety of skills, since you are responsible for all aspects of running your program
cons:
Home Office management seemed to turn away from serious issues at the chapter level
Goals seemed to continually be increased in unrealistic increments, year-to-year, leading to a high-stress environment
Occasional night/weekend work, though you could generally flex hours, depending 
Highly affected by the economy - charitable donations tend to be one of the first expenses people cut

job_title: Community Development Manager in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: LLS has a great mission and truly helps their patients! Amazing work environment and great work life balance!
cons: Not really any cons! Currently WFH due to COVID

review_title: Lost Potential, High Turnover, Expect Burnout
pros: Extraordinary passionate staff, board, and volunteers. The mission is always at the forefront and it's incredible to be surrounded by such dedicated individuals.
cons:
I wish I could say there aren't any. The reason I haven't had a complete burn out (come way to close) is because of the small but might staff I work with. I think I would have had a complete mental breakdown from the unreasonably high expectations, working on a bare bones staff, and sucking the life out of individuals who used to be passionate about non profit work. Not to mention the entire staff has already turned over with very little feedback left that new employees are left to try and pick up the pieces. 

Jobs should not suck the life and passion out of people like most positions within this organization. It should not be baptism by fire or the "sink or swim". Tend to your employees and their needs, how can you have a good organization when most of your staff across the country are too burned out to function? Enough of piling on more and more expectations, we are human, not robots.

pros: Not for Profit, great culture.

pros: LLS is an amazingly patient-focused organization who really dives head first into research, programs and services that will benefit cancer patients. It's so humbling working with the patients and providing them opportunities to come back and support the mission. The position itself is very rewarding. The individuals that work in this office will have your back from day 1 and help to ensure everything is a success.
cons: The communication is very poor. Some departments don't work on site which causes the majority of the issues in work not getting done. This has been brought up numerous times. The organization provides plenty of opportunities to provide your opinion, but nothing ever changes or is fixed. The pay isn't adjusted for cost of living which makes it difficult for someone in a large city. This office needs a HR presence due to some of the leaderships decisions and actions. Most event weeks or weekends are spent working endlessly and comp time is not accounted for.

job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: meaningful work and mission-focused overall. meaningful work.
cons: low pay, bad benefits, no leadership training

pros: Motivating and inspiring mission, and driven volunteers and staff
cons: None - great organization on all levels!

pros:
Excellent sales training opportunities in scenic locations each summer
Templates, data and resources provided for recruitment and customer service 
Frequent goal progress discussions with direct reports at both state and national levels
Heavy on customer service to high-impact (wealthy) donors and participants
Major impact on cancer treatment FDA approvals in 2017-2018
cons:
In the words of an Executive Director: “you can’t get caught in the patients’ drama. We’re focused on the bigger picture, research.”
Patient aid resources are difficult to access at best; at worst a quota has been imposed by diagnosis, without Information Resource Officers providing alternate financial aid options.
Sales culture; focus on impact, wealth, numbers vs compassion for patients & families. 
Very little exposure to patients & families for campaign staff.
Remote staff are provided very little training, support or investment.
National campaign mentors will advise local campaign staff to seek new donors or grants by looking at donors to other LLS campaigns, usually without permission from the other staff person.

pros: For Canadian branches, you receive immediate medical benefits upon employment. Salaries are competitive within the non-profit industry. Some employees really care about the cause and the people they serve.
cons:
This is for Canadian branches:
-Branches are micro-managed by head office
-Endless (mostly useless) meetings from head office to push fundraising campaigns
-Often treated as though you are incompetent from head office
-Feeling of "money first" (not people first); aggressive fundraising techniques
-Heavy pressure from management & head office if you're not reaching fundraising targets
-Large events required a lot of overtime, but management put large amounts of pressure to reduce overtime which causes a lot of stress
-Very stressful working environment, lots of pressure from management
-Very disorganized management
-VERY HIGH TURNOVER. Felt like every other week somebody was leaving the organization
-Very poor, old-fashioned types of fundraising programs that no longer work. However, head office continues to push them, even when national fundraising dollars reflect that these programs are no longer working
-Very poor office environment: not much social time or team-building 
-TOO MANY MANAGERS. Some branches had upwards of 5 managers, but only 1 admin person. Everyone at head office seemed to be a manager of some type
-Business structure did not make sense. Too much management and not a lot of productive work
-Certain employees were very rude, passive-aggressive and often nasty to branch employees. Management was aware but never seemed to do anything about it. Unsure how these people kept their jobs

pros: -learned valuable skills, positive work environment
cons: Did not have any negative expierences at LLS

review_title: When it was good, it was good...when it was bad, it was awful.
pros: They off competitive non-profit pay, excellent benefits and time off.  With a small chapter staff, each employee really has the opportunity to get their hands in all aspects of business - there is opportunity for those that are motivated.  Working towards a great mission makes any job easier and they have a great reputation for putting funds towards finding a cure.
cons: Upper management at my location often lacked tact and professionalism in many different settings.  Issues were brought to the attention of national-level HR, which seemingly chose to ignore proven complaints in order to keep a longtime employee.  The environment became way too stressful to deal with on a daily basis.  I'm sure this is not the case across the board, but was my experience at one location.

pros:
Making a difference
Love the organization as a whole just not my boss
cons:
Not flexible hours
Poor management
Unrealistic goals

pros: Loved my experience, can easily learn everything and the work environment is great!
cons: Lots of calling and sending emails.

pros: The mission of LLS  is hard to beat - the work they are doing is truly saving lives. The pay is relatively competitive for the nonprofit sector. The professionalism of the organization is unmatched in both the for profit and non profit sectors (I have worked for both). Lastly, this is a business results driven organization with a mission focus, and I love how focused we are on driving results that take $$ and turn them into life saving cures.
cons: The work life balance can be difficult (as is typical with any nonprofit fundraising position). LLS has taken steps to protect Campaign Manager and below positions by paying them hourly. This helps to control the hour load for these roles (a very forward thinking move). However, the Senior Campaign Managers and above are now often overloaded as the organization shifts hour load. The organization will need to hire additional headcount to assure that the salary employees are not overworked.

review_title: the pros and cons of non-prof work
job_title: Campaign Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: The best reason to work for LLS is that you'll get a chance to work with wonderful patients and their families as well as amazing donors/fundraisers.  I also loved most of my coworkers - we formed deep bonds from being in so many good and bad situations, and for LONG hours.  In the end, I'm glad that I was able to make a difference in the lives of our patients.
cons:
Senior staff in the Bay Area offices are not at all connected with the Campaign Managers or anyone at a lower level, so they have absolutely no idea how much time and effort we put into our jobs.  There were times when I worked 20-25 days in a row...then when I asked to take a day off, the answer was no.  

But, by far, the worst part of working for LLS is losing patients to cancer...especially when those patients have become friends.

review_title: A wonderful mission to work toward.
pros: The mission, patients and volunteers are huge motivators.  It is certainly easier to come to work when you know your efforts are going to something so important.  The pay is decent for a non-profit and if you work hard, you will be rewarded with great time off, benefits and bonuses.  The work environment was generally fun and high-spirited.  With certain positions, the ability to travel is there.
cons: There is definitely a high level of pressure when working in a fundraising position - I held positions in various departments, so I was able to see the difference when working on the administrative side.  There are some late nights and weekend work, again depending on the position.  We had some issues within our chapter that I would have liked to see resolved in a more professional manner, but the majority of my time there was great.

review_title: For the Board and New CEO
pros: MISSION, research, marketing is great.  Work life balance, compensation are good.  They let anyone work from home.  You can't beat it. People for the most part are great.
cons:
New coaching philosophy is a turn off - grabbing employees to meditate  and run through deep breathing if they perceive you need it is really not working.  We have issues to solve, let's forget this and get down to business. 
No training available at all these days. 
Some leaders have favorites who can do no wrong and are over empowered. THis will be a task for the CEO to breakdown.
I only wouldn't recommend to a friend right now because we are in an interim state until a CEO is named.
Innovation is not welcome in some areas of the business.

review_title: The people who work here only care about themselves, not the patients
pros: I was able to achieve media sponsorship that was unprecedented in the entire Society at time.  I had locally produced commercials about an annual fundraising event air during prime time evening local news.  In the industry, the news is the most sought after placement by any advertiser.  Did they appreciate it?  No, they just tried to make my job even harder.   The ED ordered all the other employees not to speak to me and they did just that.
cons: I was told when I was hired that the entire local staff would assist me in the production of a 500 person fundraising event.  They snubbed me and left me to do every single thing by myself.  I did it all by myself and did it successfully.  After the event, which was at a local park and in the evening, none of my colleagues would help me with the clean up.  I was left to clean up the huge park all by myself.  That night I injured my back when I fell out of a truck trying to load garbage.  It was there that I became disabled and could no longer work.  I am permanently disabled due to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society.

review_title: Great Mission, Poor systems and Culture
pros: Mission, Survivors, Grants to families
cons: Culture, Professional Development, Work Life balance

job_title: Campaign Manager in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: The best part about LLS is that the work is totally mission driven. You feel good about the work that you do every day and you are inspired by all of the advances in treatments that are resulting directly from the research being completed by LLS.
cons: There are a few evening and weekend events. All of them are mission driven and volunteer focused, so this isn't really a negative If you are looking for a straight 9-5 job this might be troublesome for you.

job_title: Program Aide in New York, NY
pros: The cause is important, and the people generally mean well.  Some people seem to do well here, and to enjoy the work and environment. Staff generally seem to work strictly 9-5, which is pretty uncommon.
cons:
To be fair, this was a few years ago, but my experience was not very positive:
- Diversity is extremely low, and company culture is not inclusive
- Departments are highly siloed, and some are more valued than others
- Frequently hire temporary employees, who receive low pay, are not treated as equals, and are provided few opportunities for growth/entry into the company. 
- Management is unaware and inconsiderate of issues that staff are experiencing
- Every job is essentially fundraising - there is little project management, creativity, or other skills involved, as heavy guidance comes from the national office and everything is outlined for you

pros: I feel very connected to the mission and people I work with in the office. I can tell that management is very goal-oriented and loving towards donors and patients; anyone who is affected by cancer is practically treated like family to the workers, and this makes the daily routines of checking emails and processing mail a lot better than it would be at any regular job. You can tell there is a lot of heart at this organization.
cons: While I feel deeply connected to the mission, I still feel like the organization could do a better job at making sure every day feels important to the mission. Rarely is there a disconnect, but sometimes the stress behind planning events gets in the way of seeing how much good is being done.

pros: The mission is present in everything you do and it gives you a reason to work and put in all the extra hours.
cons: The lower level employees in the chapters are under appreciated and upper level management takes advantage of the hard work that is done by the "little people." There seems to be no care for keeping employees and I have personally witnessed long term, dedicated employees being let go because of others abusing their power and trying to climb the ladder. This leaves the work environment very hostile and unenjoyable. Very much an every man for himself attitude which should not occur at a nonprofit.

pros: An amazing mission, which you can be proud of supporting. Also met very generous and kind people who are committed to ending cancer.
cons: Top management (in the home office) expects the field staff to work ridiculous hours, which in turn trickles down to middle management and below. They prey on people's desire to help the mission by not hiring enough staff to do the work adequately, and insist on financial goals that require routine 60-80 hour work weeks and weekends.Also firing incompetent workers is next to impossible, as the HR department is so terrified of lawsuits. I have worked in other nonprofits, and no other organization that I have experience with has mistreated its staff like LLS.

review_title: Amazing mission and volunteers. Everything else? Not so amazing.
pros: The mission and volunteers. Some co-workers (on the chapter and national level) actually make you feel like you're part of a "team," working to make a difference. The staff in White Plains (the non-CEO's, Field Managers, etc...) are great to work with (not to mention incredibly under-appreciated).
cons:
Lack of management (on the chapter and national level), lots of extra hours and required attendance at events. If you like the constant feeling of being frazzled and burnt out, then this is the place for you. 

LLS used to be about teamwork and the mission. Now it's about micromanagement, personal gain and more campaign revenue. There has been a definite culture change at LLS over the years and it hasn't been in a positive direction.

review_title: Rewarding organization  with staff retention opportunities
pros: Quality, trustworthy organization with a powerful objective and good intentions. Opportunities in networking, relationship building, and strategic planning are abundant. Benefits and paid time off  for full time employees are excellent. Very rewarding experiences interacting with patients, caregivers, and volunteers.
cons: LLS is primarily a fundraising organization which is not a con itself, but...  There is a heavy sales culture without the benefits of corresponding incentive based salaries or career growth within the organization. It is possible to achieve an annual performance based bonus when very specific KPI standards are met. High expectations bring high stress and low work-life balance for low(er)  pay when compared to similar work in other non-profits and in the for-profit sector. These things contribute to high turnover in many departments and positions. The high turnover has a negative ripple effect in data management, community relations, and overall chapter morale.

pros: The culture is amazing at LLS. Each day you wake up feeling that you are making a difference in patients' lives and arrive at an office full of individuals who are just as passionate as you are. The collaboration has come a long way between chapters and campaign staff. It is amazing to see our hard work on the forefront and nothing can compare to the survivor circle ceremony at Light The Night. This is the first place I worked that my employer empowered me instead of pushing me down. Besides the mission driven culture, the attention to employee's career goals and development is a breath of fresh air. If you want a job where you are saving lives and valued as a person and employee, look into LLS.
cons: It can be a good amount of weekends and night events. They are all for a cause and moving experiences but may not be for all.

job_title: Campaign Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Really good benefits/vacation time.  Good cause.
cons: I would give this place no stars.  Do not work here unless you like to be micromanaged and talked down to at every turn.  Incredibly poor management who use belittling and condescension as leadership tactics.  And that would be fine if they actually knew how to succeed and reach chapter goals, but they are completely incompetent. The chapter is run by directors who have learned to b.s. their way up to the top and do not care about the cause AT ALL.  Unfortunately the workload is by nature high and the deplorable management makes creates an even more burdensome workload.  The burnout rate is very high causing staff turnover. Very toxic work environment, not worth the poor salary.  Of course, I can only speak for the Los Angeles (now SoCal) chapter, it's possible that in the smaller chapters this would not be so common.

review_title: Local chapter was great, National management could care less about employees.
pros:
Felt great knowing you're helping to find a cure for blood cancers.
Met a variety of wonderful people
Great co-workers
Ability to work across campaigns
Felt valued by local Director
One Team, One Goal
cons:
Hours can be very long, no overtime pay
Expected to complete an impossible workload at times 
Managing (some) volunteers with very difficult personalities 
Always going back to the same "well" for volunteers, burning them out
Did not feel valued by Regional or National Management

review_title: Can't judge a book by its cover
pros: Fantastic mission, work with some real angels (both staff and volunteers), opportunity to help people on the client services side.  Team in Training helps you stay in shape.  Local volunteers are amazing.  Learned a fair amount about fundraising and volunteer management (what to do) and local board management (what NOT to do) that helped me in subsequent job.
cons: Failure on the part of HQ management to respect local boards and staff.  Insistence on adherence to McFundraising models.  Excessive politics in White Plains.  Tendency to view the chapters as nothing more than ATMs.  Disrespect for faith-motivated individuals.  The chapter executive director position, stuck between local board and inflexible field management, is often untenable.  Sadness from losing clients to these horrible diseases.

pros: Great organization mission to work for.  Working at LLS is very rewarding.   You will certainly get a diverse employment experience. Everyone is committed to the organization's mission both internally and externally.
cons: You get a diverse work experience, because each job requires a lot from the employee.   The turn-over rate is very high as a majority of the staff don't stay for very long.  Management is also challenging to work with in most instances.  Employees feedback re improvements often go unheard.  And very limited opportunity for growth and staff development.

pros: Incredible mission connections, your work moves the needle on research and patient programs.  Curing blood cancers is what they do.  It is HIGHLY meaningful and the volunteers and staff are very motivated and passionate.
cons: Very poor compensation or work life balance focus.  Highly demanding jobs with lots of nights and weekends. No upwards growth for the majority of staff.  Lots of favoritism in chapters and with national/senior management.

review_title: Totally blind to the reality of the economy and favoritism to a mazimum
pros: The patients and the ability to be compassionate with them.
cons: Those same patients you have to be compassionate with are the target of the organization preying on their emotional and psychological conditions requesting they raise thousands of dollars. Senior Leadership is superficial, cliquey, in this area, racist and totally blind to the society in the region. The pressure on the employee is too much. 6 reviews in 3mts, The positions are sales positions to meet heavy goals set by the senior managements to incur bonuses. Reviews are one sided. No praise. I actually had the Exec Dir tell me that my work was "sh*t" after securing several big companies in the region in a month. The Directors are daft incompetent and white trash who frown upon people with money. Complaints to national organization fall on def ears. Tons of intimidation. A nightmare.

review_title: Working at LLS was a mixed bag, and I am not sure I would recommend them to people seeking work.
pros:
Excellent salary compared to other non-profits.
Decent benefits.
Organization does benefit cancer patients through financial assistance and education.
cons:
Little opportunity for growth or raises.
Upper management is blind to how dissatisfied the staff is.
Poor managers mean that jobs remain stagnant and uninteresting.
Cut-throat and corporate-like environment where ideas are stolen.
Poor communication within departments, let alone between departments.

review_title: Good mission, poor leadership, poor managment
pros: My immediate team was great. The mission is compelling and the patients/volunteers make the work meaningful.
cons: I had four bosses in 2 years. 3 were internal promotions. At no point were staff consulted about our interests, priorities, needs, advice when hiring for this job that obviously had extremely high turnover. Too many people with corporate backgrounds coming into senior leadership of this large non-profit. Fundraising campaigns are now "products" and fundraising staff are called "salespeople."

review_title: No longer a good organization. Mangement changes over the last ten years have hurt this organization.
pros: Most staff  are very passionate about the cause.   Excellent benefit package for full time employees
cons: Questionable HR practices.  Over the years the company has eliminated full time positions and replaced it with temporary workers through temp agencies to avoid headcount and paying benefits.  In our chapter the receptionist was laid off in 2008.  Then a receptionist was hired via temp agency and the receptionist is still a temp position six years later.  This person has no benefits or vacation yet the job is the same as the person who did it in 2007 and was considered "staff" and paid vacation and benefits.

review_title: Expect to be worked to the bone for nothing.
pros: Mission.  The people we serve.  I had a few compassionate coworkers.
cons:
Everything else.  After over a decade in the working world, I have never had a worse working experience   There were three different people in my position in a year.  Last one lasted six months.  I realized within a week that three people working full-time round the clock could not do this job.  

Even if I had been given a realistic workload, LLS's current/previous leadership had destroyed almost every vital relationship in the territories I was assigned through awful mismanagement, thoughtlessness and years of neglect.. 

It made my job nearly impossible; added to the fact I  had no preparation time or support: I barely made it through those three months with my sanity intact. 

The  last day there was one of the greatest days of my life.

review_title: Every chapter is different - my experience with the Northern & Central Florida chapter left a lot to be desired.
pros: The best reason to work for the organization is that you will are an instrumental part of the cure for cancer.
cons: I can only speak for the Northern & Central Florida chapter.  There was no clear management or training for any of its employees.  The executive director had her own agenda and rarely did the job description meet the daily expectations.  My advice to anybody who works for the organization is to make sure you get everything in writing and make sure you communicate often with the national offices to ensure that the job you were hired to do is actually the job you are doing.

job_title: Regional Administrative Assistant, School & Youth Program in Norfolk, VA
pros: The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society provided me with the most rewarding work experience I have ever had. Their philosophy is to someday be put out of work, the work that they do is a full spectrum of services, research, and education of blood cancers to patients, families, and medical professionals. It was truly an honor to be a part of this organization!
cons: The only con that I can think of is that my employment with this organization was only temporary and part time. I would have loved to continue my employment with this organization to support their efforts.

review_title: Great mission, very low salary, very high stress
pros: No doubt LLS does great work providing resources and care to blood cancer patients, and funding invaluable research.
cons: I took a $20k pay cut over my last job (also in the development field) when I came to LLS, and that was after the hiring manager got permission to offer me $10k above the prescribed salary range.  The job was extremely high stress with long hours, and my supervisor repeatedly threw her staff "under the bus" in order to save herself.  The turnover was extremely high (my entire team quit around the time I did), and management was lacking on the local level.

review_title: Great cause, but don't expect to be valued for your hard work
pros: Knowing that you are truly making a difference in the community, a great cause, and a great way to meet great people (fundraising participants)
cons: Expect to work really long hours, and when your hard work gets noticed and you get promoted, expect to work even longer hours, and get almost nothing for a raise. Expect to have zero work-life balance, and have to sell your soul for the organization. And no matter how hard you work, you will be expected to do more. It's never enough. Good talented people with good, fresh ideas don't get rewarded.

pros: Mission is awesome. Co workers are dedicated.  Volunteers are inspiring.
cons: Salary is very low even compared with other nonprofits.  National management increasingly rigid:  demands uniformity and not open to innovation at the chapter level.   Creativity not valued. Management is reactive not proactive when problems occur and  decision making is extremely slow.  High turnover.  Lip service to collaboration.   Antiquated  fundraising software.  Challenging environment where you are expected to succeed even when set up to fail. Limited advancement opportunities with too much politics and playing favorites. Over reliance on temps.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
pros: Great mission; wonderful co-workers and staff who are excellent at their jobs; job satisfaction knowing you are contributing to a good cause
cons: Lots of turnover; overworked and underpaid employees, even after multiple record-setting years of fundraising (i.e. positions elminiated, increased hours) ; most issues stem from the chapter leadership; lack of trust in management

review_title: Great Mission, incredible people involved,.......... thats it
pros: The overall mission of the organization and everything that has been accomplishment since day one has been incredible. The people involved with the organization are compassionate and devoted to do more to achieve the goal of the mission.
cons: High stress, low pay position. Upper management is way too overly unrealistic in numbers during fiscal year. I agree with other reviewers that there is a LOT of favoritism with many staff members and many double standards. Highly inappropriate and unethical actions on a daily basis.

review_title: Inspiring Mission and Great Place to Work!
pros: The mission of the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society is to help raise funds to find a cure for blood cancers. This is especially important since Leukemia affects many children. The company offers career advancement in the non profit sector and offers valuable experience in the fundraising sector as well. Must of the workers have a passion for fundraising and knack for getting people excited about raising the funds. Team n Training offers regular people the opportunity to train for a marathon, triathlon and century cycle ride, and raise funds for cancer research and hopefully a cure!!! Really a dynamic place to work.
cons: With certain positions, the hours can be very irregular and that makes it difficult if you have a family.

review_title: Sucked the living daylights out of me.
job_title: Campaign Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Best reasons I can think of is its mission and those staff who work at the bottom (assistants, interns and temps) are truly genuine.
cons: I have way too much to say here. MICROMANAGING AT ITS WORST. First off, they let people go for no reason, have you sign a contract to confirm that you quit on your own so they don't have to pay you unemployment and WILL NOT give you a reason as to why they let you go. Secondly, they have no respect for their staff. The entire organization was jewish women, no offense but where is the DIVERSITY? and finally, they instill such fear in you that you lose all your confidence and passion for working in nonprofits. I had a horrible experience at the Red Cross but this place topped it off. DO NOT WORK HERE.

review_title: Churn and Burn Non profit Mentality
pros: LLS provides great opportunities for young professionals, helping you learn the ins and outs of the non profit industry.  Some management are great employees and have become more mentors.  Overall, the people at LLS are outstanding.  LLS also does a great job connecting you to the mission and making you feel included.
cons: Senior leadership at LLS thought if you left, you can be replaced (and cheaply).  Salary is low, typically below average for non-profits and you are expected to work whenever they say.

job_title: Team In Training Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros:
-mission oriented
-great people to work with at chapter level 
-great place to learn a range of skills and then take elsewhere - great first job
cons:
-lack of transparency from national office, the decision makers
-recent downsize in Team In Training that has not being handled well - did not have all answers to questions about the downsizing when it was rolled out, etc. 
-a lot of "on the job training" rather than true professional development trainings 
-at the chapter level, they're making the culture more fun- office ouppy visits, cereal breakfasts as a staff, yoga classes during lunch sometimes

review_title: Great Company To Work For, Clicky Environment
pros: The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society is a great company to work for when it comes to the cause. what your goal is, and helping to fight against blood cancers.
cons: What I did not like about working at the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society was how uncomfortable and clicky the environment was.  Some of the women were unkind, although some were not.  It wasn't a warm environment.  The woman who ran the walk in Essex County a few years ago was extremely rude and unpleasant.  Some of the people who worked here are unprofessional.

pros: The mission is worthwhile and the employees are great to work with (but not management).
cons: No training on process or procedures and what little there is, is over 5 years old.  Outdated and poor database.  Multiple reporting systems with uneven reporting information.  Management cares only about how much money is coming in.  Posted as 35 hours per week but in reality is closer to 45 to 50 and includes multiple weekends and evenings.  This would be okay except the pay is substandard.

job_title: Campaign Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good benefits, flexible, good networking if you work for a major fundraising campaign. If you want a job where you are not behind a desk and get to network with a lot of different people this is good for you.
cons: This is one of the most mismanaged, low strategy, unrealistic, disrespectful, confused, deluded places I have ever worked. Things are getting better but very slowly. The turnover is HUGE, the management is poor, the culture is unprofessional. Long hours, low pay. HR is awful and not on your side. They let people "go" wontonly. Unethical.

pros: LLS was a good stepping stone into the work force. You could get accustomed to office life, dress code, meetings, etc. Very mission centric giving a lot of appreciation back to the patients, donors and volunteers! Creating a long lasting relationship with patients, donors and volunteers was very easy and incredibly rewarding in the long term. Dr. Lou, CEO is sensational!
cons: No work life balance, terrible management on a local level. Very little to no appreciate given to the staff in office.

pros: Most people were had good intentions and were well meaning and believe in what they are doing.  Friendly.  Good benefits.
cons: Little work life balance (work nights & weekends + 9-5), low salary, 95% of the jobs are fundraising.  Most of the people get their first job out of college because they don't know what it means to make a decent salary or have normal hours.  Also non-profits tend to be slow to adept to change, thus are stuck using inefficient systems and fundraising methods that "work" rather than adapting and allowing for creativity. All of the above result in a high turnover rate.

pros: Great work environment. Very friendly co workers. Laid pack office environment.
cons: The pay is very low. Makes it hard for them to compete with other organizations. Turn over seems to be high because most companies pay more then what is offered at LLS.  This position is best suited for someone  just coming out of college who lives at home or with a roommate and needs some valuable experience. Not recommended if you have a lot of financial obligations.

pros: Great survivors and volunteers. Great cause.
cons: Money focused not people focused. Lost focus on Mission due to ambition. Patient and professional support reduced to almost token level. Employees are ruthless internally in pursuit of "success & advancement". It is very competitive, You cannot trust anyone.Office culture not embracing of diversity. Employees have no voice. Poor work-life balance. Promotions only for those who know how to apple polish, do not ever challenge leadership, or have someone who likes them in leadership.

review_title: Mission is amazing but organization does not provide support for success of employees.
pros: The survivors you meet and hear their stories of overcoming the diseases touches your heart daily. Research is key and LLS spends accordingly.
cons: Employees fend for themselves and does not lend to team efforts.  Existing staff does not trust new personnel and has a clique feeling among coworkers. Sink or swim mentality on education of employees. Short career life spans with those with tenure about 3  years.

pros: Mission, research, work done for patients.  Overall it could be a great organization if there wasn't so much politics.
cons: New CEO needs new voices  the ones he is listening to are not to be trusted. They are running the good leaders out of town, she has a spy in each department who need to try and keep their jobs. There is No where to turn because the reporting structure leads you to the main problem!  The CEO is portrayed as a figure  head.  Get a new Senior team. They are undermining you!

pros: Working at LLS means connecting with people affected by cancer. It can be incredibly inspirational and empowering to be a part of such a strong community of cancer research advocates.
cons: Working in a chapter office of LLS means getting through a lot of red tape to get things done. The National office-to-chapter relationship is complicated and bureaucratic. Clear communication and transparency were always issues during my time there, and I think LLS is still working to navigate the complexities of standardizing practices for over 50 chapter offices. LLS is also woefully behind in their technology and it shows in their chapter-specific marketing collateral. Nobody should have to use Microsoft Publisher to create marketing pieces.

review_title: National and volunteers don't always acknowlege the work it takes to fundraise but in the end, it is very rewarding.
pros: The people you meet connect to the mission and their stories is very humbling.  We have some of the best volunteers in the non-profit sector!!
cons: National doesn't alway recognize the work of the fundraisers.  Chapter management seems to very, but my manager and exective director are always ready to acknowlege our work.

review_title: Rewarding but not recognized for the hard work.
pros: Great time off (vacation,etc).  Love the interaction I have with Team In Training participants.  I really enjoy what I do.
cons: I'm confused how people get promoted or just keep their jobs.  No one wants to deal with conflict and tell someone they are not doing their job correctly.  Low pay!  Not recognized for the hard work and long hours .  If I'm such a "valued employee" than treat me like one!  Management does not mentor employees to achieve career advancement.

review_title: Review of Temp Job at Leukemia & Lymphoma Society
pros: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society is a very open, transparent operation, from what I could see. Employees at all levels make themselves available for suggestions. Accordingly, opportunities to move upwards are there for those looking for them.
cons: If you are not specifically interested in the mission of LLS, the job can be less than satisfying. It can feel like just another job in fundraising.

review_title: Good Organization. Poor experience with senior chapter staff.
pros: Good people (staff & volunteers) helping those battling cancer. Highly rewarding to help facilitate life saving research. LLS has an array of initiatives that strategically fund research and accelerate the approval process for new therapies.
cons: Pay.  Depending on position and supervisor, expectations of time commitment and schedule can be skewed. Management didn't seem to understand the significance of how its decisions affect staff professionally, while at LLS and especially beyond.

job_title: Senior Campaign Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: The mission and the people.  You will find some of the most amazing reasons (ie. patients, dedicated co-workers) to work here.
cons: There have recently been many changes and cuts to the organization that is making it difficult to complete tasks with confidence.  There is a lot of pressure placed on staff to work with limited resources.

pros: Mission is always first and foremost. Working at LLS affords you the opportunity to see impact from your fundraising and meet those that you are influencing. You will instantly get great volunteer leadership experience and new thoughts, program ideas are highly encouraged. It is very campaign driven and focused. Relationships are built through event fundraising in many forms.
cons: The salary below director level is not significantly competitive with similar non-profits. With event based fundraising, focus is less on larger gifts and more on longer hours in campaign driven relationship fundraising.

job_title: Campaign Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: LLS attracts really great people, the people are the best part of working there. There are also great benefits and most holidays are honored.
cons: Employees aren't valued from the top down and there is very limited room for growth or career expansion. As an employee you don't feel like you are very appreciated beyond the local level and compensation is on the low end and an uphill battle to increase. There is a VERY high turn over rate. Communication from upper/national management is also poor when it comes to changes and reorganization.

pros: Inspiring mission, dollars spent wisely; CEO and Senior Leadership have a great vision; rewarding day-to-day work, partnering with volunteers and being part of campaign growth
cons: Environment varies from Chapter to Chapter depending on local leadership. My Chapter’s culture is toxic; morale and turnover is horrible. HR has not been receptive to concerns. EDs don’t seem to have a clear role or accountability.

pros: Wonderful cause. Light the Night is an inspirational amazing event to be part of.
cons:
National Office - doesn't support regional employees. Advised of new 'core values' and told we can be open and share what we think, opinions. When you do that, then you get criticized or punished for it.
- Low Pay, minimal benefits
- Working overtime is part of the job - you don't get paid double time, you get time off in lieu
- Upper management is not supportive; if they don't like you, then you will know it.
- no room for movement / growth
- lack of recognition or rewards for a good job / performance

pros: The mission is incredible!! You can feel proud that you are working for an organization that is really doing something that is doing the good fight against cancer. You really meet some fantastic people who are also passionate about the cause.
cons: It was never clear what you had to do to get ahead, but you quickly knew if you were one of the people that would get promoted or not. Managers were never educated in learning how to get the best out of their employees. The work could easily get boring and many co-workers complain about their jobs. Many people are not happy and it shows.

review_title: Great Coworkers, Great Mission, Poor Administration
pros: You will be working with an extremely passionate group and wonderful volunteers. The events are really fun and meaningful. There are some great wins to celebrate around survivorship, research and fundraising
cons: The pay for the industry is generally low. There is a  LOT of turnover. The national office is a mess and administration overall is very poor. I have been here going on 4 years now and there has never been a smooth or clear direction for staff training, promotion, or the campaigns in general.

review_title: Great mission, local leadership needs direction.
job_title: Senior Campaign Manager in Dallas, TX
pros:
Have saved countless lives as a result of their work and advancements in blood cancer research.

Passionate volunteers and board members.

Staff truly do care about their work.

Really enjoyed being there.
cons:
Data management and record keeping is sorely lacking. Information is kept in numerous Excel spreadsheets, in numerous locations, and is hard to find or paint the bigger picture of corporate partnerships. Much of the information are met in people’s heads.

Local leadership is steering the ship without a compass. Everything is typically done last minute and in rush, despite the event occurring on an annual basis.

review_title: 5 Years and the Timer Has Run Out....
pros: The Mission is an amazing one and every day I feel fulfilled in my job. I love the volunteers. I love my co-workers. I have been able to make an amazing contribution over the past five years. My local office has worked with me after I had my baby and allowed me extreme flexibility and support. The people I work with are amazing (in my office).
cons:
* Very low pay for how hard we work. Pay seems to be arbitrary and based on items that I have never seen. I am looking for work now that pays a liveable wage as I have become a breadwinner for my family. I pay almost $600/month for insurance! 
* National Management, National Board, and new CEO are out of touch. I predicted the fall of TNT over three years ago. Yet.....no one cared about what anyone thought that wasn't in the "in" crowd. 
* Very reactive. Not proactive. 
* Locally I have amazing leadership---though we have been without an Executive Director for over 4 years and cannot get one. It's chapter suicide. 
* I always have the feeling that there is no communication at the top. It is very top heavy. They laid off 50 people before our fiscal year but promoted, hired, and reassigned more than 50. Why do I need 3-4 bosses?
* I really wonder about the long-term health....I imagine some huge issues in the next few years...

pros: I worked there because I cared about the patients and used to like the team I worked with.
cons: Top management is corrupt and inept. The former CEO had no integrity and he surrounded himself with people like him. They have created a mess with the regional structure , it is not working. Lou DeGennaro pushed for the advocacy agenda of Access and Cures and destroyed the Patient Services department one person at a time. If he is made CEO, the org. will not survive. He is part of the problem along with the advocacy people he has hired. Truly sad to see. Dwayne Howell is surely missed.

review_title: Blood cancer is an important area of innovation and research breakthroughs, much of it fueled by LLS.
pros: Lots of people who have a passion for the cause work there. Solid research funding success and clinical partnership track record. Strong fundraising brands.
cons:
Frequent restructuring! Disconnect between executive leadership and the ‘tribe’ nationally and regionally. 
Difficult organization to navigate. Top down and silos endure. 

The org. could be so much more successful if employees felt treated fairly and empowered and donors were valued and respected appropriately. 

Patient centricity is weak.

review_title: Worst Job Experience I've Ever Had
pros: The mission is wonderful, and you can really see it at work throughout the DFW metroplex.
cons: The company culture in the Dallas office is abysmal and lacking any direction. You are chastised for trying to learn, then slapped on the wrist for attempting to do your work - there is no winning situation. Work/life balance is nonexistent and the work is thankless. National is way too involved and micromanagey, setting unrealistic goals and offering "help" in all the wrong ways. In no way are you set up for success. Appearance and perception are valued higher than work ethic. Again, there is no winning situation; this office is a nightmare.

pros: I've been at LLS for several years and am constantly inspired by the results of the dollars we raise.  The research team at LLS is choosing the right scientists and therapies to fund and as a result, we're seeing new cancer treatments come to market left and right.  The staff and volunteers are some of the most passionate people I've ever had the pleasure to work with and their tenacity is infectious.
cons: As with any nonprofit, the work can be grueling and employees have to keep an eye on maintaining work / life balance.

pros: The mission of LLS is what drives me through the job every day.  Being able to interact with walk teams and my amazing volunteers.  They are the ones who lift me up and give the job meaning.  The advancement of cancer research and Dr. Lou's work is incredibly inspiring.
cons:
Unfortunately, the mission can only take the employees so far.  I took a major pay cut in hopes for a better quality of life and a job that really gave meaning.  Non-profit work should be fun, ESPECIALLY AT LLS because of the work that's being done, but it's not because there's a major disconnect between national and the chapters.  National is amazing and chapter leadership is not.  The "leadership" in the chapter have no experience on how to lead people, they just simply delegate, down grade, and do everything in they power to burn you out. The women I work with are gossip queens and it's overall, a toxic work environment. Leadership was not honest with me about this position when I interviewed....
The quality of life has been about the same from my last job if not a bit worse with the long evening hours and weekend work for little to no pay. I have had friends ask me if I could refer them on to work at LLS and I've had to be honest and tell them "you do not want to work here, based on my experience. I would hate to set you up for failure."  It's a shame because LLS could be so much better!!

job_title: Event Planning Intern in Overland Park, KS
pros: Everyone was really nice and always tried to find ways to give me hands on experience. I learned a lot about the event planning industry and the logistics that go along with it. Heather Harper was an amazing woman and helped me in any way she could.
cons: When I applied for the internship the title online was Public Relations and Event Planning Intern but when I started working there the work was only Event Planning. While I appreciate the experience, I was disappointed that I didn't get any experience with Public Relations since that was also apart of the job description.

review_title: A great mission with operations that need refining.
pros: Nationally LLS does a phenomenal job of helping individuals with Leukemia, Lymphoma and Myeloma.  Their Team In Training program provides a win-win situation for both the Society and the Athlete.
cons: When issues occur their tends to be a failure to examine the whole picture.  There is an air of favoritism and an atmosphere where gossip is taken as fact than getting to the truth of the matter.

pros: LLS does a fantastic job of integrating the mission into daily work life, and the rewards received from making connections with patients and families is priceless. LLS is truly on the brink of curing blood cancers.
cons: ZERO work/life balance!  Employees of LLS are usually fresh out of college and willing to work around the clock for very little money.  This is not the place to work for someone with a family.  Attending numerous events on evenings and weekends is often a huge waste of time, and are almost always overstaffed.

pros: Great cause and hard working staff
cons: No diversity, both in color and ethnicity as well as gender as men make up roughly 5% of the organization's staff and leadership.

review_title: Accustom to high turnover so not committed to lots of training
pros: It is an organization with a great cause and you have the opportunity to work with wonderful people in the public sector.  Being able to help patients and their families during a time in their life that is difficult is a very rewarding job experience!
cons: It is very low pay as with most nonprofits, and in my particular position there was lots of hours expected with small rewards and very little understanding of one's personal time

pros: Supporting families in need after a cancer diagnosis.
cons: Poor management and training. Each campaign manager is required to handle ALL aspects of their own campaign, leading to quick burn-out and lots of things falling through the cracks. Very sales-oriented. Moving up in the organization purely comes from total dollar amount raised (if you are assigned to a poor-performing campaign, your results may not reflect the work put into the project).

pros: Tons of training - fairly flexible, autonomous work environment, peers were the best
cons: ED had a problem with drinking and it was embarrassing!  HR absolutely knew and did nothing other than a slap on the hand.  The board knew and did nothing.  Any HR issues with staff were met with " find some way to work it out" - The payscale is not to scale.

review_title: Great cause, but full of cancer
pros: Mission is prominent in your everyday work, the cause really support local patients, finding cures and helping, volunteers are dedicated and motivated to help
cons: Internal issues with upper management make it very hard for staff to be successful, those who work closely within the organization know how inappropriate the things that are happening in the office are, double standards and guilt are utilized often to try to get results

review_title: Who you know gets you promoted
pros: Leadership is trying to make changes to make pay and promotions more fair. The health insurance is great but expect a high deductible plan as your only option by 2017.
cons: Technology is a MESS! So is HR.  The CFO has a huge amount of power.  There simply arent enough checks and balances with business-minded people making decisions.

review_title: Great experience for entry level but not a place for career
pros:
Mission to cure blood cancer
Great benefits (vacation, sick, personal days, medical, dental, vision)
Tech savy organization although some processes should be streamlined
cons:
Long hours, nights and weekends. Expect to work at least 2 weekends each month
No opportunities for professional development or continuing education
Unprofessional work environment
Compared to other non-profit organizations, LLS employees are underpaid

job_title: Outreach Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I met a few really amazing individuals during my time there.
cons: The definition of mismanagement - the worst organization I have worked for. Turn over at the hub was ridiculous - over 14 people quit in a matter of 5 months. I was just informed, over voicemail by an outside agency, that our hub would be dissolved and our last day is this Friday. The only reason I was still there was to finish up the last 3 weeks we had scheduled for outreach. They pulled the rug out from under us. I'm blown away by the heartlessness especially to the employees that were left standing after all the rest came and went because management lacked the ability to motivate and encourage their staff.

pros: Wonderful mission and advances in science.  Committed staff driving toward cures. Innovative in fundraising approaches.  Engagement with FDA and pharmacy allowing advances otherwise not possible.
cons: Top heavy management.  Finance focused on small issues as opposed to looking at large revenue streams and return on investment.  Lack of streamlined CRM affecting donor engagement.

pros: Employee's are challenged with meaningful work and have the opportunity to collaborate cross-functionally.  Incredibly dedicated team. Most positions offer flexibility and consider work-life balance. Competitive and comprehensive total compensation package. Recognition encouraged, provided and shared from within and outside of respective business areas.
cons: Coming from for-profit, the difference in available resources and support is apparent.  Individuals who are self-driven, agile and not risk averse can thrive. Individuals preferring a steady pace may not be best suited.

review_title: Has a vision without a plan
pros: Great mission & cause. Feel great every day knowing the work you do is helping so many blood cancer patients
cons: Frustrating organizational structure with a lack of strategy to accomplish big goals. Very reactive vs being proactive, which creates a feeling of constant change.

pros:
-The mission is one you can get behind and the staff really believes in their mission
-Flexible schedule/Good work life balance
-The donors/volunteers that work with this organization are passionate about LLS and that gets you as the employee excited about your work
cons:
-The local leadership doesn't support all of their staff and play favorites for certain campaigns
-Because of. this,  you can feel lost sometimes on what you are supposed to do or what is next
-Tenure is more important than what skills the employee actually brings to the table

review_title: Great cause, but employee moral is very low.
pros: The mission.  The only reason I stay is I know I'm making a difference in the lives of the families affected by blood cancers.
cons: Employees burn out quickly due to unreasonable expectations and poor work-life balance.  No matter how hard you work and how much you succeed, it is never enough.  Focused too heavily on the revenue and not enough on relationships.

pros: Everyone is very passionate about the cause!
cons: Not enough support for remote workers (they try but just mostly talk, not enough action) and they refuse to hire an assistant for those that work alone in remote areas though the OT is usually 200 hours per year; The Canadian society needs to get more organized and connected to each other across provinces. None of the tech equipment they provide works and alays tech issues with online systems.

pros: Great mission and humble CEO.
cons: The Nebraska chapter Executive Director makes our office life a nightmare. She makes a terrible first impression as it looks like she rolls out of bed to come to work. She constantly starts drama in the office by gossiping about her subordinates and is constantly complaining about her health, board members and personal life. Everyone has to walk on eggshells and it’s a very toxic work environment.  All my colleagues love their job but are all looking for other opportunities because of one person!

review_title: Wonderful and Fulfilling Place to Work
job_title: Customer Support Representative in San Diego, CA
pros: I love my time at LLS. It is a wonderful organization that truly gives meaning to coming to work everyday, knowing that we are doing our part to cure cancer. I work in the Contact Center, so there are pros to speaking with our donors, patients, and volunteers each and every day.
cons: It is a non-profit, and like most nonprofits salary are not usually in line with what you would imagine yourself making, unless you are high management. There is a lot on your plate due to not enough budget resources.

review_title: Great place to work hard and gain experience
pros:
casual work environment
substantial freedom to run own program
positive interactions with patients & families
one team- one goal mentality
cons:
long hours and unreasonably high expectations
little flexibility in compensation
inaccurate information about how much raised actually goes to patients
